Name: Rohit B
Title: Ancient & historic
Review: Some monuments stand as a piece of our history, with not much to do or see around. Dilkusha Kothi is one such abandoned place, but a nice picture spot for the avid traveller.

Name: silva s
Title: Hidden gem
Review: A piece of forgotten history. We loved the quiet winter morning here. photography lovers will also appreciate the place.

Name: pilgrim_gsa
Title: Oozing with history
Review: This must no be missed for it's ascociation with Awadh history as also 1857 .There are also British graves from that period .

Name: Tanvi
Title: Visited here with family
Review: If you love history don't miss this place if you are in Lucknow . I visited here with my family and had a good visit .

Name: Pushpendra M
Title: HISTORICAL PLACE
Review: If you are history lovers then this place really for you. Its really amazing place and vert attractive.

Name: Dhyan Chand
Title: Historical monument
Review: In a Lucknow cantt Historic monument situated just 5 km from Hajratganj. That is Nabab of Lucknow's temporary resistance when he go hunting.

Name: baburammarch25
Title: Great example of indo- French fusion architecture.
Review: It is located near the cantonment area of Lucknow, comprising of great Indo- french architecture and massive gardens. Fortunately this place is well maintained!

Name: Ashutosh Misra
Title: Dikusha Gardens and Palace in Lucknow
Review: Most of the tourists will surely miss this awesome place. This located right next to Lucknow cantt area and close to posh Vikramaditya Marg in Lucknow. Palace was built by the British with French design for the Nawabs of Lucknow. It's a must visit place if you happen to be in Lucknow.

Name: 592abck
Title: Nice palace
Review: This palace has a good history and also well maintained. We saw many tourists here who were interested in knowing more.

Name: Aarav K
Title: Fantastic
Review: This is a great place to spend some time with your friends. Dilkusha is a very old building in which you will see a lot of things. Have fun by going at least once.

Name: ashok_shrikhande
Title: Dilkusha Palace
Review: The Kothi and its adjoining magnificent garden were created by Nawab Saadat Ali Khan. It is almost an exact replica of an English country house called Seaton Delavel in Northumberland, England, built in 1721.It was initially intended as a hunting lodge for the nawabs although, it was later used as a summer resort too. The building had patterned walls and unusually no inner courtyard.It faced major impact during the first war of independence and hence lies in a less than perfect state with just a few towers and walls standing.

Name: PD1059
Title: Old world charm with garden
Review: It is a great place to visit provided you keep in mind that you need to be secure especially because the place is visited by few people and have a deserted look.

Name: authorneelesh
Title: Must go Must see
Review: Part of the residency complex, the magnificent building now in ruins among lovely landscaped gardens is an integral part of the history of Lucknow.Part of the residecny complex , the review of that will cover this as well

Name: pinaki50
Title: Beauty in ruins
Review: We had heard about a beautiful well maintained garden called dilkusha gardens but what we saw were remnants of a classic architecture called Dilkusha kothi - a really enormous hunting lodge of yesteryears, now in ruins. Surrounded by a carpet of green n some well maintained colourful foliage this rubbled structure is a mosaic of the past n the present. Worth visiting as it's only short drive from the city centre.

Name: IndiTales
Title: Handsome ruins
Review: The ruins tell the story of the architecture of Lucknow. Place is absolute ruins but whatever remains is nicely maintained.

Name: SabujSen
Title: War memorial..
Review: Part of the Lucknow residency . It is with in the city and well communicate. It occupies a vast area and it's well maintains. One can get to see the ruins of British colonies which were demolished by our National Freedom fighter. It Carries Some heart wrenching moments during the sepoy mutiny.

Name: Ujjwal S
Title: Nics but not worth the visit.
Review: Its simply a garden.. you can visit lohia park instead .. its better than this.. this place has some historical significance but not worth the expectations.. U ll find only local couples there who want privacy.. not much local people go there..

Name: Utsav_Garg
Title: Peaceful place
Review: I have visited this several time and its a nice place to relax, Big gardens with ruins of nawab's monument.Nothing much to see but really good place to relax.Its 4-5KM from hazratganj on Sultanpur road. Its in cantt area.

Name: Pallavi S
Title: Good for a picnic with family
Review: The ruins of the building are surrounded by pretty lawns that are perfect for a picnic. The ruin itself is interesting. You can see what an impressive building it must have been before it was turned to rubble.

Name: Chelsea E
Title: Pristine Gardening Amidst Nawabi Ruins
Review: I visited Dilkusha Kothi and was expecting to be able to wander around inside ruins as is often the case with ruins in India. There is no doubt that the Dilkusha Kothi is in ruins, however, due to barred doors there is no way to go inside, and one may only look inside from said barred doors. However if there were a way to go inside it might not make much of a difference as there's not a whole lot to the structures themselves. I found it interesting that there was a British person's grave next to one of the two kothis. If you wish to pay homage to the era of Wajid Ali Shah you will find helpful informational telling about how the properties were used as summer homes for the Nawab and his family, and that at one time the grounds nearby were also used for military trainings, which the British apparently did not like. Worth seeing if you are interested in the history. The premises is pristinely well-kept and has an open grassy space for picnicking as well as some nice shade trees.

Name: Ankur B
Title: Escape place from hustle and bustle of Lucknow city
Review: Dikusha is a complete makeover from what it was 20 years ago. As a child I used to pass this place and never dared to enter as it looked barren. Go to this place now, it has beautiful lawns, the building is repaired and painted. For history lovers, which I am not, it gives you the feel of Nawabi culture. If you are looking to find a quiet place to escape from the crowd, plan a visit to this place.

Name: Amitava_dg
Title: Nice one but at a desolate place
Review: Not much remains of once a palace of Nawabs. But the ruins and the solitude provides a traveller much welcomed respite from touts and crowds of major sites.

Name: Siva M
Title: An incomplete History Still captures your imagination- Worth a Visit
Review: This is not for you if you do not have good imagination or if you do not like history. This campus is hidden behind the CM's residence and is a very peaceful place as very few people some here. The construction of the Palace was stopped due to the orders from the Queen, but the shear layout of the walls of the side palace tells you the grandeur of the planners. The yard is impeccable. One has to imagine how the emperor Shah Alam would have thought of this place. One distinct aspect of this place is there is no evidence of any strategic plan by the emperor in case there is an attack by an enemy unlike what you often see in other Mughal palaces.

Name: Aman A
Title: A Palace at some time but now in ruins
Review: This place is located in the cantonment area of Lucknow. This building which once used to be a palace now lies in ruins but still a very nice and peaceful place to visit.As the place is in cantonment area and that also in the outer cantonment area, it hardly has much of visitors and you might also find vacant streets at this place. Travelling after sunset to this place is highly not recommended.

Name: Rudrapratap R
Title: good place for solitude and history lovers
Review: Dilkusha kothi was constructed by great nawab of awadh sa-adat ali khan. its a ruined building but you can visit if you history lovers .not recommend for family fun

Name: SjAwadh
Title: What is left of a grand history of Nawabs  !!!
Review: 1. Dilkusha literally means " Heart's delight " and this is the place which once comprised a grand building and surrounding gardens .2. The Dilkusha kothi, now in ruins, was a European - style building made in 1800 for the then Nawab of Awadh .3. At that time , this was a semi -forest at the banks of river Gomti in the outskirts of the city of Lucknow . The Nawab used this place as a hunting ground and for family leisure .4. During the The First War of Independence in 1857 , a considerable damage occurred to this building as at that very time the British had occupied the building.5. Now this place is under Lucknow cantt area and the ruins and surrounding lawns are maintained by ASI .6. Lucknowites prefer this place for picnics in winters and it is a favourite place for school picnics and cultural events are also organised in the open area .7. The place is a little secluded and no proper public transport is available here ,so, it is better only to visit in day time .

Name: JAGDISH RAVAL
Title: A HISTORICAL PLACE
Review: Dilkusha Kothi  is a historical Place. It was Built in the year 1800. This monument was once a hunting lodge as well as a summer retreat of the rulers. The building was designed in the European Baroque style. The huge pillars on the front, grand steps leading to those pillars are examples of this style of architecture. The Archaeological Survey of India has taken up steps to preserve this place and today, the park around this monument is a favourite place for visitors, mostly during winter for the glorious sunshine.  Please do visit to this marvellous piece of architect

Name: Rajpriyagarv
Title: Lovely place
Review: Well maintained monument which is also used to host cultural events also. Must visit during winters as during this time one would enjoy sound and light shows obout Rumi or other events that may be happenening

Name: iSaurabh S
Title: Not worth visiting
Review: Not a good maintained place. Do not go in dark at all.. the locality is not safe. Even in broad daylight there is nothing to see much other than broken monument.

Name: wish2traveltheworld
Title: Quiet Place
Review: If you want to enjoy the calm for sometime then come to this place which is free from a lot of tourists. It is just old ruins of some sort of palace where nawabs used to live and also have some history from british era. The garden outside is too good.

Name: Chetna1973
Title: Well maintained and serene
Review: Dilkhusha is close to La Martinere College and can be clubbed with a visit to the school.Though in ruins, it is well maintained, set in manicured lawns, in a quiet serene location. Just right to stroll into, sit and read a book, spend a little time reminiscing or just be by yourself and your thoughts.It is not a very large enclosure and can be visited in a short span if sitting around is not an option.

Name: Durgesh K
Title: Kothi DIlkusha
Review: An ancient palace of British Era just outside of Lucknow. Remains gives a glimpse of the architecture of that time. Not much time is required to visit the place. 1 or 2 hour may be sufficient. Also not a prioritized place to see if you have some time spare you may visit.

Name: Taz_Bh
Title: Small, Beautiful.
Review: Nothing much to see, but the architecture and the lawns are quiet calm. The architecture is also pretty. We were kinda racing against time, when I decided to ensure we saw these before I left...I would recommend it. Though it is not one of the famous over touted attractions of the city. I would definitely recommend intellectuals and history seekers to visit.

Name: SUROJIT G
Title: Off the tourist track
Review: Work visiting to soak in the ruins of the hunting lodge of the former nawabs of Lucknow set amidst lush greenery

Name: Lorie22
Title: Definitely a 'heart's delight'
Review: A lovely, peaceful park with the ruins of two eighteenth century buildings built by the Nawab of Oudh for his friend the British Resident.  During the Mutiny of 1857 they suffered serious damage. Henry Havelock, the British General, died here in November 1857.

Name: sherurhino
Title: ruins
Review: must get it to heritage sites and penalise people that tamper the same... good gardens and only ruins that are very poorly maintained. except a mali/gardener one saw nothing.

Name: ApurbaRoy
Title: Picnic
Review: A good spot for picnic with family and friends. It is peaceful area also. Even school children also find their place here en-mass along with school instructors

Name: Priya B
Title: Quaint and peaceful
Review: It's a quiet and peaceful place to visit. It is surrounded by a garden. We took some good pictures. ASI renovation was going on when we were there.The Chief Minister's residence is near to it. It is a 10 minutes' worth visit.

Name: abhineetsingh
Title: Dilkusha Kothi
Review: Amazing place in cantonment area of Lucknow...up keep is ok...ruins tells the story of great architecture and glory of this place...very peaceful , neat and a good place to visit...

Name: Pawan_Shrotria
Title: Peaceful
Review: Good to go for a peaceful time pass. Just wander or sit anywhere. Peaceful atmosphere and away from the hassle of the city.

Name: Yorkie1970
Title: Lovely site next to the gardens
Review: Great little site with the preserved ruins of the two neoclassical Dilkusha Palaces. Very little interpretation but gatekeeper does speak a little English. Great free attraction!

Name: Swatimathur
Title: Very good
Review: Another excellently well maintained monument in Lucknow, Dilkusha is beautiful by day and night, when it gets lit up.

Name: bishwaksen
Title: Nice out of the way place
Review: This is a complex which lies a bit away from the more famous attraction of the city. The complex contains two big manor houses nestled amongst a lot of trees. Since its not very popular, you will be able to explore in peace. The Dilkusha Kothi was modelled on an English manor house and you can still see the underground chambers used by the maids, the towers on 4 sides, the fireplaces etc. At places, you can also see the original decoration. It won't take more than 30-45 minutes to see everything, but there is not point in going if you don't like historical buildings/ruins. The ASI has recently started renovating it. The caretaker of the place is a nice friendly man. He opened all the locked gates and guided us into the interiors of the houses, chatted with me about the place and pointed out all the interesting sights.

Name: Debarati D
Title: A piece of history amidst soothing greenery
Review: Dilkusha Kothi was a palace built in the English baroque style in the quiet Cantonment area of Lucknow , India.All that remains today of the magnificent structure are  a few towers and external walls. All the roofs are gone. The house was profusely shelled when Lucknow was sieged by rebel Indian soldiers of the British East India Company during the 1857 uprising. This damaged the structure permanently.The marks of shelling are clearly visible on its walls even now.But you can still see the lush green lawns which once surrounded the Kothi. The house was constructed around 1800 by the British resident Major Gore Ouseley, a friend of the ruler of Awadh, Nawab Sadat Ali Khan. It was initially intended as a hunting lodge for the Nawabs. It was later used as a summer resort too. There is also another smaller building on the premises. This was built by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah for military exercises which he had to abandon because the British rulers objected to it.The remains of the building, the lawns and surrounding gardens have been currently restored by the Archaeological Survey of India(ASI). There are no guides available. But the signage provided by ASI has sufficient details. After leisurely walk exploring the place, we settled down to a nice little picnic in its gardens. There are a very few garbage bins. So we carried back our trash till we found one. Ideal place to enjoy  lush greens while remembering an important era of India’s history.

Name: ar_faraz
Title: CALM, GREEN, HISTORICAL PLACE
Review: Its a really nice small place of Lucknow. Its very near to main Lucknow City. Having 2-3 Lush Green Lawns with Ruins of Old Dilkusha Kothi Palace. It as originally built as hunting lodge of NAwabs of Awadh.
